title: CTRL0000038858 - Transcribed Interview of Alex Jones, (January 24, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
DEPOSITION OF:
ALEXANDER JONES
Monday, January 24, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:04 a.m.
Present:
Representatives Lofgren, Murphy, and Aguilar.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:

NORM PATTIS
This is a deposition of Alex Jones conducted by the House Select
Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol pursuant to
House Resolution 503.
This deposition is being conducted remotely through the Webex platform.
This will be a staff-led deposition, though members may choose to ask questions
as they so desire.
We're currently joined by Mrs. Murphy.

the basis for his privilege is, as I evaluate it, and it's on my advice that

he's giving it, is as follows.
There appears to be a very broad and wide-sweeping -- an increasingly broad and

watched this clip, the "he" that you're mentioning is your lawyer, Mr. Pattis.

At one point in this clip, Mr. Jones, you describe documents that

I raise this clip to you at the beginning of our conversation today to illustrate a
point, which is that the Fifth Amendment protects your right to refuse to answer
questions if the truth would, in fact, be incriminating.
In other words, invoking the Fifth Amendment means that you have a good-faith
belief that if you were forced to tell the truth, you would be testifying in a manner that
you believe could be used against you in criminal prosecution.
Do you understand that?
Mr. Pattis.
Well, I'm going to object to that characterization of the Fifth.
The
law is that it tends to incriminate, whether -- and so I'll object to that characterization of
it for the sake of the record.
It's whether it would tend to incriminate in the eyes of a prosecuting authority.
Whether it's truthful or not in his mind is not the question.
Having said that, Mr. Jones?

to remain silent.
